channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Israel Built a Modern-Day Trojan Horse: Exploding Pagers
item.description: The Israeli government did not tamper with the Hezbollah devices that exploded, defense and intelligence officials say. It manufactured them as part of an elaborate ruse.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Ronen Bergman and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Wednesday mourning the deaths of four comrades killed in the explosions.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Finds Way Around Brazil Ban and Goes Live Again for Many Users
item.description: Elon Musk’s social network used a technical maneuver to restore service for many Brazilians after a court blocked it. Regulators expected to restore the block soon.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters criticizing the Brazilian Supreme Court’s decision to ban X during a demonstration in São Paulo this month.

item.title: Second Wave of Hezbollah Devices Explodes in Lebanon, Killing at Least 20
item.description: At least 20 people were killed and more than 450 others wounded, Lebanese officials said, a day after pagers exploded across the country and killed 12 people, in an attack widely attributed to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Ambulances arriving after a device reportedly exploded during the funeral in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Wednesday for people killed when hundreds of pagers exploded across Lebanon a day earlier.

item.title: Child, 10, Stabbed Near Japanese School in China
item.description: A 44-year-old man was in custody, the police said, after the child was attacked Wednesday. Other Japanese schools in China urged caution.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: Shenzhen, the city in southern China where the stabbing occurred.

item.title: Pager Attacks in Lebanon Puncture Hezbollah’s Image as Powerful Anti-Israel Force
item.description: Two series of coordinated attacks targeting the group’s wireless devices caused thousands of injuries, piercing the group’s rank and file and raising questions about how it will respond.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Outside the American University of Beirut Hospital on Tuesday, where many people injured in Tuesday’s attack were taken.

item.title: Bishop Casey Was Laid to Rest in Galway Cathedral. His Secrets Were Not.
item.description: The funeral of Bishop Eamonn Casey in 2017 seemed to draw a line under his scandalous affair years before. But this summer, disturbing new allegations emerged.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bishop Casey’s funeral in March 2017. His burial seemed to end a scandal involving a consenting adult, but disturbing new accusations emerged this summer.

item.title: Israel’s Pager Attack Was a Tactical Success Without a Strategic Goal, Analysts Say
item.description: By targeting so many pagers at the same time, Israel demonstrated technical prowess and partly restored the aura of its intelligence agencies. But its long-term intent is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Inspecting a car in which a pager exploded in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: An Ugly Divorce, Russia’s Richest Woman and a Deadly Shooting in Moscow
item.description: The Russian businesswoman Tatyana V. Bakalchuk has been locked in a dispute with her estranged husband for months over the fate of her company, Wildberries.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Russian police officer blocking the entrance to the office building of the Russian retailer Wildberries, after an shooting there on Wednesday.

item.title: Pavel Kushnir Dies in a Russian Prison
item.description: Among the hundreds of Russians jailed for criticizing the war in Ukraine, the death of Pavel Kushnir in detention has transformed him into an antiwar symbol.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

item.title: What We Know About the Deadly Wireless-Device Explosions in Lebanon
item.description: The seemingly coordinated blasts targeting Hezbollah members stoked fears of a broadening conflict.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Eve Sampson
item.media:description: An ambulance carrying wounded people at the emergency entrance of the American University hospital in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Kashmiris Are Voting Again. But Do They Have a Voice?
item.description: An election that began on Wednesday will restore some of the self-rule India took away in 2019. But a lasting chill has fallen over Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Showkat Nanda
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Kulgam, in southern Kashmir, lined up on Wednesday to vote in Kashmir’s first regional legislative election in a decade.

item.title: Russia Seizes Town in Donetsk as Ukraine Hits Ammunition Depot
item.description: The capture of Ukrainsk underscored Russia’s steady advances in the Donetsk region. Ukraine is trying to counter with strikes on Russian military infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A still from a video posted on social media of smoke and flames after a Ukrainian drone attack in Toropets, Russia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Taiwanese Company Gold Apollo Says It Didn’t Make Pagers Used in Attack
item.description: The company, Gold Apollo, said it had not manufactured the devices, pointing to another company that it said was licensed to use its brand.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the Gold Apollo factory in Taipei, Taiwan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Bangladesh, Struggling to Restore Order, Gives Army Policing Powers
item.description: Public disorder has continued in the country, weeks after its autocratic leader was driven out by protests. Many police officers have still not returned to work.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers on the streets of Dhaka, Bangladesh’s capital, in August. The army has been carrying out law enforcement duties for weeks, a former officer said.

item.title: Their Countries Are at War. These Couples Are Still Together.
item.description: Relationships between Ukrainians and Russians have long been common. Russia’s invasion has brought stigma, separation, legal troubles and a reconsideration of identity.
item.dc:creator: Laura Boushnak, Alan Yuhas and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

item.title: Methane Levels Still Rising, Despite Global Methane Pledge
item.description: Satellite data shows the U.S. releasing more and more of the potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, researchers said, despite pledges to cut back.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: The concentration of methane in the atmosphere is now more than two-and-a-half times greater than preindustrial levels.

item.title: Tropical Storm Pulasan Nears Shanghai After Grazing Japan
item.description: Pulasan was expected to make landfall near the Chinese financial hub by Friday morning. Forecasters warned of potential floods and landslides.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Shanghai was bracing for Tropical Storm Pulasan days after it was battered by Typhoon Bebinca, the strongest to hit the city in 75 years.

item.title: U.N. Body Demands Israel End Its ‘Unlawful Presence in the Occupied Palestinian Territory’
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of the U.N. General Assembly voted in favor of a nonbinding resolution calling for Israel to end its occupation within a year. The United States was among the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Riyad Mansour, left, the Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations, applauding the result of a vote during an emergency session at the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Derision of Haitians Goes Back Years
item.description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s false comments about pet-eating Haitian immigrants are the latest in a pattern of attacks against people from the Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An asylum seeker from Haiti was cleaning the kitchen of a migrant shelter in Tijuana, Mexico, as former President Donald J. Trump debated Vice President Kamala Harris this month.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: A Second Day of Explosions in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, Kamala Harris courts Latino voters.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters mourned the deaths of four fighters.

item.title: Israel’s Focus Shifts From Hamas in Gaza to Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description: Daily exchanges of fire between Hezbollah and Israel have been destructive, disruptive and sometimes deadly. An escalation could risk starting a wider regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters mourned the deaths of four of the group’s members, on Wednesday.

item.title: Walkie-Talkies in Lebanon May Have Held More Explosives Than Pagers
item.description: The blasts on Wednesday involved bigger, heavier devices that set off more large fires.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Aric Toler

item.title: Husband Is Indicted in Double-Murder Case Involving an Au Pair
item.description: Prosecutors in Virginia said the case involved a hidden love affair and sex arranged over a fetish site.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal

item.title: Tyson Is Sued Over Labeling of ‘Climate-Smart’ Beef
item.description: An environmental group said the company, a major food producer, was misleading shoppers with its claims about eco-friendly practices.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Brazen Beef, a new Tyson Foods brand with packaging that uses the language “climate friendly.”

item.title: Floods Wreak Havoc Across Four Continents
item.description: Flooding events around the world share a common factor of an atmosphere made warmer by climate change. What can be done to help citizens prepare?
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney and Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: The swollen Elbe river in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: Wireless Device Explosions Are Latest High-Profile Attack Attributed to Israel.
item.description: Israel is believed to have conducted a series of clandestine attacks on adversaries linked to Iran in recent years, sometimes using highly innovative tactics.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, Iran’s top nuclear scientist, was killed in 2020 by a truck-mounted machine gun attached to remote-controlled robot.

item.title: What Is Hezbollah, the Militant Group Based in Lebanon?
item.description: A series of attacks on wireless devices has drawn attention to the Iran-backed militia. Here’s what to know about the militant group.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters carrying the coffin of a senior commander, Fouad Shukr, who was killed in an airstrike in July in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

item.title: Blinken Visits Egypt, but Skips a Stop in Israel
item.description: The secretary of state is making his 10th visit to the Middle East since the Oct. 7 attacks. Until now, he has met with officials in Israel each time.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s decision not to visit Israel partly reflects a deadlock in efforts to strike a cease-fire deal in Gaza.

item.title: Funeral Is Held for 9-Year-Old Girl Killed in Pager Attack in Lebanon
item.description: “The enemy killed us using this small device!” mourners chanted at the funeral for Fatima Abdullah, a fourth grader.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral for Fatima Abdullah, who was killed when a pager exploded in her home, in Saraain, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: What Are Pagers? Devices Exploded Across Lebanon
item.description: Pagers lack more modern navigation technologies so can be harder to track, but are still widely used in hospitals for their reliable service.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pagers at the Gold Apollo factory in Taiwan on Wednesday.

item.title: England and Wales Will Introduce Buffer Zones to Ban Protest at Abortion Clinics
item.description: “Safe access” zones outside clinics in England and Wales will make it illegal to harass anyone seeking medical services or working there, the British government said.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Lucy North/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An anti-abortion demonstration outside Britain’s Parliament in May. The new measures cover protests up to 500 feet from a clinic.

item.title: How Colorado’s Thompson Divide Got Protection From Oil and Gas Drilling
item.description: The members of a self-described ragtag group had little in common, but their campaign could serve as model for future environmental efforts.
item.dc:creator: Zoë Rom and Eli Imadali
item.media:credit: Eli Imadali for The New York Times

item.title: Europe’s Floods Are Another Sign of Growing Threat of Climate Change
item.description: Climate change is influencing extreme weather events like the flooding across six countries that has led to mass evacuations of cities as the waters continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Rescue workers evacuating flooded areas in Ostrava, Czech Republic, on Monday.

item.title: U.N. Sees ‘Human Rights Abyss’ in Myanmar as Military Kills Civilians
item.description: Three years after the military staged a coup, intensifying a civil war, civilians continue to pay the price, according to a coming United Nations report.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from an armed insurgent group in Myanmar walked through a church damaged by the military in southern Karenni State in January.

item.title: Cathy Merrick, 63, Advocate for Indigenous People in Canada, Dies
item.description: She was on the front lines of dogged fights against injustices, including a recent series of murders of Indigenous women by a white man.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Kim Wheeler

item.title: Exploding Pagers Targeting Hezbollah Kill 11 and Wound Thousands
item.description: The Iranian-backed militant group, which uses pagers to safeguard communications, blamed Israel for the attacks in Lebanon. Israel declined to comment.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward, Ronen Bergman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: After hundreds of pagers exploded across Lebanon, the wounded were rushed to hospitals in ambulances, like this one in Beirut, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Planted Explosives in Pagers Sold to Hezbollah, Officials Say
item.description: Small amounts of explosive were implanted in beepers that Hezbollah had ordered from a Taiwanese company, according to American and other officials briefed on the operation.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Ronen Bergman

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Exploding Pagers Kill at Least 9 in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, China’s “silver economy.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Lebanese army soldiers in the streets of Beirut yesterday.

item.title: Biden Administration Extends Review Period for Nippon Takeover of U.S. Steel
item.description: U.S. Steel’s chief, David Burritt, expressed confidence on Tuesday that the sale of the American manufacturer to a Japanese owner would close “on its merits” despite bipartisan backlash.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: David Burritt, chief executive of U.S. Steel, has warned that the company could lay off workers and relocate its headquarters outside Pennsylvania if the deal were blocked.

item.title: Second Apparent Assassination Attempt on Trump Prompts International Alarm
item.description: There is widespread concern that the November election will not end well and that American democracy has frayed to the breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump speaking onstage during the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee in July as a photograph of the aftermath of an assassination attempt was emblazoned on a screen.

item.title: With Sandbags and Team Spirit, a Polish City Fought Off a Flood
item.description: Thousands of residents of Nysa, in southern Poland, formed a human chain overnight to pass each other sandbags, building a wall along a river embankment to keep the raging waters at bay.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Anatol Magdziarz
item.media:description: Local residents pile up sandbags to protect the embankment of the Nysa Klodzka River against the floods in Nysa, southern Poland.

item.title: Iran’s Ambassador to Lebanon Is Injured in Apparent Pager Attack, State Media Reports
item.description: The ambassador, Mojtaba Amini, lost an eye, according to two members of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps who were briefed on the attack.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iran’s ambassador to Lebanon, Mojtaba Amini, center, in Beirut, Lebanon, in July.

item.title: A Look at Israel-Hezbollah Tensions and How a Wider War Could Impact Lebanon
item.description: Hezbollah and Israel have repeatedly traded strikes since the Gaza war began in October, killing civilians and combatants in Lebanon and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the funeral of a commander in August, in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: $50 Billion in Aid to Ukraine Stalls Over Legal Questions
item.description: U.S. and European officials are struggling to honor their pledge to use Russian assets to aid Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s leader, and President Biden held a news conference during the Group of 7 Summit in Savelletri, Italy, in June.

item.title: Manchester City’s Premier League Hearing, Explained
item.description: The world’s richest soccer league accused its champion of years of financial violations. A hearing that began this week could tarnish the club’s accomplishments and reshape the competition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The charges date back to 2009, a year after Manchester City’s purchase by the brother of the ruler of Abu Dhabi. That acquisition began a turbocharged era of spending — and success.

item.title: Burning Oil Tanker in Red Sea Is Towed to Safety
item.description: The delicate rescue mission aimed to head off a major environmental disaster after the oil tanker was attacked by Houthi rebels off the coast of Yemen last month.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The oil tanker Sounion in the Red Sea on Saturday. It has since been towed to safety.

item.title: What to Know About the France Rape Trial of 51 Men
item.description: Prosecutors say that, for almost a decade, Dominique Pelicot drugged his wife to rape her, alongside dozens of other men he invited to abuse her.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, 71, arriving at court in Avignon, France, in September to testify against her former husband.

item.title: Portugal Going Through ‘Difficult Days’ as Wildfires Burn Across the Country
item.description: More than 5,000 personnel are battling a number of wildfires, the authorities said, and the prime minister called it an “extremely difficult weather situation.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A helicopter dropped water to try to contain a fire in Albergaria-a-Velha, Portugal, on Monday.

item.title: What Is JNIM, the Al Qaeda Affiliate Claiming Attacks in Mali?
item.description: An extremist group that claims allegiance to Al Qaeda said it was responsible for assaults on a military police school and an air base in the West African country of Mali.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Smoking rising in the distance behind crowds in Bamako, Mali, on Tuesday after an attack. The violence could raise questions about the security strategy of the country’s military leaders.

item.title: Von der Leyen Doles Out Top E.U. Jobs
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen named her choices for the European Commission as she navigates a host of challenges, including the rise of nationalist forces.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Union’s executive arm, presented its new leaders on Tuesday in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Trudeau’s Liberal Party Loses Parliament Seat in Montreal Special Election
item.description: The election in Montreal had been seen as a referendum on Canada’s deeply unpopular prime minister, who has faced calls from within his party to quit.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s approval ratings have stagnated just above 20 percent for the past year.

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu Considers Firing Defense Minister Gallant in Government Shakeup
item.description: Dismissing the minister, Yoav Gallant, would remove a frequent critic of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a time of mounting tensions with Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant at a news conference in Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: Ukraine-Russia War Updates: Moscow Hits Back in Kursk as Air War Heats Up
item.description: Moscow’s troops have retaken a few villages in a border area that Kyiv’s forces invaded last month and are also advancing steadily in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Haley Willis
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the move in an armored vehicle in the Donetsk region on Sunday.

item.title: Hamas Plans Future in Gaza After Surviving Israel’s Onslaught
item.description: Khaled Meshal, one of Hamas’s most senior officials, said in an interview that the militant group expects to play a decisive role in the enclave when the war is over.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: People walking on a street in Khan Younis, in the south of the Gaza Strip, on Sunday.

item.title: Dominique Pelicot, Husband on Trial for Drugging and Raping Wife, Testifies
item.description: Dominique Pelicot, who is accused of inviting strangers to rape his wife while she was drugged and unconscious, took the stand for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, center, the ex-wife of Dominique Pelicot, arriving at the Avignon courthouse with her lawyers on Tuesday.

item.title: Meta Plans to Ban the Russian TV Network RT
item.description: The owner of Facebook and Instagram said it would bar Russian media outlets including RT, while YouTube is removing channels it had already blocked.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Meta, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, said the ban would take place in the coming days.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Suspect is Charged in Apparent Trump Shooting Attempt
item.description: Plus, why you should binge “Shogun.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roads to Donald Trump’s golf club in West Palm Beach, Fla., were closed off yesterday.

item.title: Thierry Breton, Top E.U. Commissioner, Resigns, Citing ‘Questionable Governance’
item.description: The surprise resignation of Thierry Breton came after he accused Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, of pressuring France to nominate another candidate instead of him for commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Thierry Breton, France’s European Union commissioner, meeting in Brussels in June.

item.title: Brazilian Politician Upends Debate by Hitting Opponent With Chair
item.description: The stunning attack on live television is likely to reorder the race to lead São Paulo, Latin America’s largest city.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Mr. Marçal, at a campaign event earlier this month, has shaped his political style in the mold of other brazen right-wing leaders like Donald J. Trump and former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro.

item.title: Death Toll Rises as Deadly Floods Threaten Central Europe: What We Know
item.description: At least 17 people have died and thousands have been displaced. “Relief is not expected to come before tomorrow, and more likely, the day after,” an official in Austria said.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: An aerial picture of the flooded town of Klodzko, southwestern Poland, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Ramps Up Air Assault on Ukrainian Cities
item.description: An attack on Kyiv early Monday was the eighth on the Ukrainian capital in about two weeks, officials said, adding that most of the incoming Russian drones had been intercepted.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian police officer helping a civilian leave the site of a missile attack in Kharkiv on Sunday.
